author: By Sheera Frenkel
title: Lies on Social Media Inflame Israeli-Palestinian Conflict
description: Misinformation has flourished on Twitter, TikTok, Facebook and other social media about the violence between Israelis and Palestinians.
content: In a 28-second video, which was posted to Twitter this week by a spokesman for Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel, Palestinian militants in the Gaza Strip appeared to launch rocket attacks at Israelis from densely populated civilian areas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Shpigel
title: Tom Wilson Is Hockey’s Chief Villain. Or Is He?
description: The Washington Capitals forward plays like a freight train, and it gets him into trouble. He is the teammate that everyone wants and the opponent that everyone loves to hate.
content: Washington Capitals forward Tom Wilson, according to some of his peers, is a menace. A bully. A punk. A goon. He is reckless, vicious, dirty, and bad for hockey. He might have fit in 30 years ago, but his conduct — illegal checks and high hits, at the price of five suspensions in his career — has no place in today’s safety-conscious N.H.L.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ann Carrns
title: How to Navigate a Hot Housing Market
description: Competition for homes in many cities is leading potential buyers to take steps they may not have considered a short time ago, including waiving the inspection.
content: The home-buying market this spring is not for the faint of heart.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niraj Chokshi
title: Delta will require that new employees be vaccinated.
description: Unvaccinated employees could face restrictions, like not being allowed to work on international flights.
content: Delta Air Lines will require new hires to be vaccinated against the coronavirus, but will exempt current employees from that mandate, making it one of the first major corporations to embrace such a requirement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sapna Maheshwari
title: Consumer Spending Flattens After March Jump, a Sign of a Rocky Recovery
description: Retail sales held steady in April after rising 10.7 percent the previous month, as Americans continued to spend government stimulus payments.
content: Retail sales were flat last month after a buoyant March, the Commerce Department said on Friday, as Americans continued spending their latest round of government stimulus checks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times Opinion
title: Scorecard: Winners and Losers of New York’s Mayoral Debate
description: Opinion writers and outside contributors give their rankings of the Democratic contenders for "the second toughest job in America."
content: Welcome to the Times Opinion scorecard for New York City’s first mayoral debate of 2021, which featured the eight leading Democratic candidates on Thursday night. A mix of Times writers and outside political experts assessed the contenders’ performances and ranked them on a scale of one to 10: one means the candidate probably didn’t belong on the virtual stage and certainly not in Gracie Mansion; 10 means he or she is ready to take over from the current mayor, Bill de Blasio, who can’t run again because of the city’s term-limits law.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Politi
title: Uruguay has the world’s highest death toll per capita.
description: Contagion rates in the country began inching up in November and soared in recent months, apparently fueled by a highly contagious variant first identified in Brazil.
content: BUENOS AIRES — For most of the past year, Uruguay was held up as an example for keeping the coronavirus from spreading widely as neighboring countries grappled with soaring death tolls.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: A C.D.C. About-Face
description: The C.D.C. responds to scientific evidence and says vaccinated people rarely need masks.
content: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention is finally catching up to the science.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Zimmer and Apoorva Mandavilli
title: How the United States Beat the Variants, for Now
description: The country has managed to avoid a variant-fueled spike in coronavirus cases. Scientists say we were lucky.
content: On Dec. 29, a National Guardsman in Colorado became the first known case in the United States of a contagious new variant of the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rana F. Sweis and Vivian Yee
title: Protesters in Jordan march to the Israeli border in support of Palestinians.
description: Before the protesters could reach the demarcation line, however, the riot police blocked their path.
content: AMMAN, Jordan — Thousands of protesters in Jordan, Israel’s eastern neighbor, marched toward the border on Friday morning, chanting slogans in solidarity with the Palestinians and waving Palestinian flags as Jordanian riot police surrounded them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Miller
title: Shohei Ohtani Unleashed
description: With the so-called Ohtani rules junked, the Angels’ “super freak” is dominating as a hitter and a pitcher. “There are things that he can do on a baseball field that other people can’t.”
content: ANAHEIM, Calif. — Seventy-two years after his death, Babe Ruth, again, is having a moment. So, too, are Ted Radcliffe, Harvey Haddix, Sudden Sam McDowell, Bullet Joe Rogan, Leon Day and many others.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah E. Bromwich and Andy Newman
title: Rash of Subway Attacks Raises Worries With 24-Hour Service Set to Return
description: Hours after mayoral candidates clashed over how to address crime in the transit system, the police reported a series of early-morning assaults.
content: In the span of 12 minutes early Friday, the police said, a group of men attacked commuters aboard a moving subway train, increasing concerns about public safety in New York City’s transit system just as 24-hour subway service is set to resume on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Arthur Lubow
title: What You Didn’t Know About Barkley L. Hendricks
description: The less celebrated side of the artist’s career, his photographs, receive deserved attention in a new book.
content: Barkley L. Hendricks portrayed Black people who exude attitude. “In the Black community, you stand out because you declare your own sense of identity beyond your environment,” said his longtime friend Richard J. Watson, artist-in-residence at the African American Museum in Philadelphia. “When you see yourself shown as a standout — and not because you haven’t eaten in three days and you’re a symbol of poverty — that gives you respectability.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Cowan
title: Uncovering the History of America’s First Koreatown
description: Friday: A Korean-American professor discusses the most gratifying research of his career, into Riverside’s Pachappa Camp.
content: Good morning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush
title: Biden revokes more of Trump’s executive actions, including moves on immigration and monuments.
description: The actions represented a broad repudiation of former President Donald J. Trump, and his practice of using executive orders to advance his political agenda.
content: The Biden administration on Friday revoked a Trump-era restriction on migrants who enter the country without health coverage and rolled back six executive orders intended to stoke anger over street protests and attacks on Confederate monuments in 2020.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Creswell
title: A Tahini Lemon Cranberry Bar Dreams of Whole Foods
description: With workers at home and stores stingy with shelf space, how is a new protein bar supposed to introduce itself? Even the food giants had to adjust.
content: Lupii bars were supposed to have a breakout year. Or, at the very least, be something people might have heard of.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Leonard
title: Why Charles Koch Wins When Our Energy System Breaks Down
description: When the next crisis hits the Colonial Pipeline, it will once again shut down. Panic buying will resume. And people will ask, yet again: How did this happen?
content: When the Colonial Pipeline shut down in 2016, it sent a grave warning about America’s fragile energy system. Once the gasoline stopped flowing, thanks to an accidental breach by a construction crew in Alabama, millions of people along the East Coast who relied on the nearly 60-year-old, 5,500-mile-long sometimes leaky pipe for their daily energy needs suddenly felt marooned. Backup supplies dropped. Prices spiked in some markets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: When the Bus No Longer Rolls Into Town
description: The final shutdown of Greyhound bus service in Canada will add to a growing accessibility problem for rural communities.
content: Given that Greyhound had already suspended operations for about a year because of the pandemic, its announcement on Thursday that it was permanently ending all of its remaining bus service in Canada was almost symbolic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bernie Sanders
title: Bernie Sanders: The U.S. Must Stop Being an Apologist for the Netanyahu Government
description: America has a role to play in bringing peace to both Israelis and Palestinians.
content: “Israel has the right to defend itself.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Palmer
title: From Newsroom to Classroom: When Times Staff Members Double as Professors
description: While teaching important skills and values to the next generation, they also find opportunities to learn.
content: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Schechter
title: Immerse Yourself in Indigenous Culture
description: From Virginia to California, these eight parks, heritage centers and open-air exhibits offer fresh opportunities to confront the history and the present-day realities of Native Americans.
content: Cultural attractions like theaters and museums took a hit during the pandemic. But for those interested in heritage tourism or Indigenous culture in the United States, immersing yourself can be done safely and simply, outside.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: Going on a Scavenger Hunt to Finish Your Kitchen Renovation
description: Since the pandemic has driven home renovation costs up, how about some secondhand ways to save some money?
content: I recently showed up at the Habitat for Humanity ReStore in Randolph, N.J., about 10 minutes after it opened, and already the warehouse was full of customers looking for secondhand light fixtures, door knobs, bedroom sets, sofas and windows.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tammy La Gorce
title: On Parole, Staying Free Means Staying Clean and Sober
description: A program called Swift, Certain and Fair — a set of principles  for both supporting parolees and holding them accountable — can help reduce recidivism.
content: Joy Thompson was in her early 50s when she started using opioids.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anthony Tommasini
title: Bach Invented. Now a Pianist Is Trying to Match Him.
description: With “Inventions/Reinventions,” Dan Tepfer fills out Bach’s missing two-part inventions with daring free improvisations.
content: “Of course Bach is a million times greater than me,” the pianist Dan Tepfer said recently. “I can still have a conversation with him.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: The new U.S. guidance on masks is ‘a ticket to freedom,’ but comes with questions.
description: New federal guidance from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, which cleared the way for people in the United States who are fully vaccinated against the coronavirus to drop mask-wearing in most situations, still came with plenty of caveats and confusion for Americans on Friday. It sent state and local officials, as well as private companies, scrambling to decide whether and when to update their own rules.
content: New federal guidance from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, which cleared the way for people in the United States who are fully vaccinated against the coronavirus to drop mask-wearing in most situations, still came with plenty of caveats and confusion for Americans on Friday. It sent state and local officials, as well as private companies, scrambling to decide whether and when to update their own rules.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: America’s Next Move? Vaccinate the World.
description: Vaccinating the world is possible. The United States should lead the way.
content: The United States is well on its way to protecting Americans from the coronavirus. It’s time to help the rest of the world. By marshaling this nation’s vast resources to produce and distribute enough vaccines to meet global demand, the United States would act in keeping with the nation’s best traditions and highest aspirations while advancing its geopolitical and economic interests. It is a moment of both obligation and opportunity.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Fully Vaccinated Can Shed Masks, C.D.C. Says
description: Quotation of the Day for Friday, May 14, 2021.
content: “We have all longed for this moment. If you are fully vaccinated, you can start doing the things that you had stopped doing because of the pandemic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer
title: Police Received Worried Calls Days Before North Carolina Killings
description: In the days before a 13-hour standoff with the police, the authorities repeatedly heard of a man’s deteriorating mental health. The standoff ended with four people and the gunman dead.
content: For two years, Isaac Barnes became increasingly paranoid.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Graham Bowley
title: A Kevin Spacey Accuser Tried to Sue Anonymously. A Judge Said No.
description: As sexual assault cases proliferate, judges must weigh accusers’ requests for anonymity against the tradition of open courts and fairness toward defendants.
content: The man said he was 14 years old when he was sexually assaulted by the actor Kevin Spacey in the early 1980s. Last year he filed a lawsuit against Mr. Spacey in which he sought to maintain anonymity, identifying himself in court papers only as “C.D.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rosalie R. Radomsky
title: His Song Got Her Attention
description: At a karaoke competition in 2014, Mary Crowley heard Justin Douds sing “I’m just a bachelor. I’m looking for a partner.” The words rang true three years later.
content: Mary Alexandra Kougeas Crowley perked up her ears when Justin Warren Douds sang “I’m just a bachelor. I’m looking for a partner” the winter of 2014 at a karaoke league competition at a Washington bar. Neither, though, was looking for a partner at the time.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Agnes Callard
description: The [DATE] episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
content: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Agnes Callard. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Timothy Egan
title: The Hoover Dam Made Life in the West Possible. Or So We Thought.
description: Climate change threatens Las Vegas and every other desert oasis town.
content: LAKE MEAD, Nev.— Few things force you to confront hubris and genius at the same time as much as the magnificent harness on the Colorado River that created the largest reservoir in the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marcelle Sussman Fischler
title: The Hamptons Boom Continues
description: Home sales and rentals on the East End of Long Island picked up at the beginning of the pandemic and are still going strong.
content: The high-flying Hamptons real estate market continues to soar.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David G. Victor, Sadie Frank and Eric Gesick
title: We’re Not Ready for the Next Big Climate Disasters
description: Any infrastructure bill should include money to protect communities from flooding, storms, drought and wildfires.
content: The infrastructure bills taking shape in Congress will be the first test of the Biden administration’s ability to legislate on climate change. Most eyes are on how greener infrastructure can cut emissions of warming gases.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Goldberg
title: How Republicans Could Steal the 2024 Election
description: Liz Cheney's ouster showed that the G.O.P. is still at war with democracy.
content: Erica Newland serves as counsel for Protect Democracy, a nonprofit organization founded in 2017 to fight democratic breakdown in America. Before Joe Biden’s victory was officially confirmed in January, she researched some of the ways that Donald Trump’s allies in Congress might sabotage the process. She came to a harrowing conclusion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Preston
title: Breathing Through the Rectum Saves Oxygen-Starved Mice and Pigs
description: Japanese scientists who studied an unusual method of delivering oxygen in mammals hope to one day try it in people.
content: Dr. Caleb Kelly, a gastroenterology fellow at Yale University, was recently asked to review a paper about mammals receiving lifesaving oxygen through their anuses. “I laughed, to be honest,” he said. “I thought it was a joke.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gia Kourlas
title: Review: A Choreographer Looks Back on His Pandemic Year
description: Stephen Petronio’s virtual program, presented by the Joyce Theater, explores isolation, longing and legacy, but doesn’t take those issues to a deeper place.
content: The choreographer Stephen Petronio is easing into veteran status, having formed his company in 1984 and created a steady stream of dances since. But when he was first figuring things out, Trisha Brown gave him — he was the first male dancer in her company — what every young dance artist needs. She rented him a space in the basement of her loft. “I had 5,000 square feet for a $100 a month for many years,” he said during a virtual Joyce Theater discussion in April, “and that launched my career.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex T. Williams
title: Your Car, Toaster, Even Washing Machine, Can’t Work Without Them. And There’s a Global Shortage.
description: This is what supply chain fragility looks like.
content: As the fallout from Covid wreaks havoc on supply chains, a major economic and geopolitical tug of war has broken out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gold
title: “We would hate to use the mute function on anyone”: Virtual debate leads to some awkward moments.
description: In the first hour of the New York City mayoral debate glitches were rare, though at one point Andrew Yang appeared to be stuck on mute.
content: At the start of tonight’s debate, Errol Louis, the lead moderator, asked the candidates about policing in New York City. As each spoke, the others listened quietly, waiting for their moment to speak.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Roth
title: The 1,000-Year Secret That Made Betta Fish Beautiful
description: Scientists found that the fish were gradually domesticated like dog breeds into the beautiful shapes and colors that turn up today in pet stores.
content: For centuries, humans have been captivated by the beauty of the betta. Their slender bodies and oversized fins, which hang like bolts of silk, come in a variety of vibrant colors seldom seen in nature.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Benjamin
title: Elise Stefanik Is Playing a Dangerous Game With Her Career
description: For those who have  followed her career, her embrace of Trumpism doesn’t come as a big surprise.
content: The rapid rise of Representative Elise Stefanik of New York to the post of chief pro-Trump messenger in the ongoing battle for the soul of the G.O.P. has sparked a flurry of media reports about how a supposed onetime moderate Republican metamorphosed into a full-fledged fire-breathing far-right conservative.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carol Rosenberg and Julian E. Barnes
title: Guantánamo Detainee Agrees to Drop Call for C.I.A. Testimony
description: Under a deal with the military court, Majid Khan, who has admitted being a courier for Al Qaeda, will give up his chance to call witnesses to his torture in return for being released as soon as next year.
content: WASHINGTON — A detainee at Guantánamo Bay has agreed to a deal intended to lead to his release in the next few years in return for giving up the right to question the C.I.A. in court about its torture program, United States government officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger and Nicole Perlroth
title: Pipeline Attack Yields Urgent Lessons About U.S. Cybersecurity
description: The hack underscored how vulnerable government and industry are to even basic assaults on computer networks.
content: For years, government officials and industry executives have run elaborate simulations of a targeted cyberattack on the power grid or gas pipelines in the United States, imagining how the country would respond.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andy Newman and Jonah E. Bromwich
title: N.Y.C. Mayoral Candidates Keep Focus on Crime After a Feisty Debate
description: Back on the campaign trail, the leading Democrats traded barbs over their competing visions for public safety.
content: On the day after the leading Democratic candidates for mayor faced off in the first major debate of the election season, Andrew Yang attended a conference on the future of the waterfront. Scott M. Stringer went to a vacant lot in Brooklyn to talk about affordable housing. Maya Wiley toured a Puerto Rican cultural center on the Lower East Side. Eric Adams attended fund-raisers, and Raymond J. McGuire greeted business owners on Staten Island.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Weinstein
title: Just-Right Recipes
description: These are the meals of the moment: glazed tofu with chile and star anise, crispy grains and halloumi, and chicken katsu.
content: The sun is out. I’ve made my annual switch to iced coffee. I’m buying Lambrusco and making a spritz. Summer is nigh! After the year we all had, you will catch me indoors only when it’s time to sleep, shower or type on this laptop (and maybe not even then).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Morales
title: Andre Hill’s Family Reaches $10 Million Settlement With City of Columbus
description: Mr. Hill, 47, was fatally shot by a police officer in December while he was in a garage. An agreement announced on Friday paves the way for the city’s largest settlement.
content: City officials in Columbus, Ohio, have agreed to pay a $10 million settlement to the family of Andre Hill, a Black man who was fatally shot by a police officer in a garage in December.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alix Strauss
title: How Dr. Wafaa El-Sadr, Epidemiology Professor, Spends Her Sundays
description: Throughout the pandemic, nothing has stopped her from going into the office every single day (with fresh flowers).
content: Even though she is a lauded epidemiologist, Covid’s severity took Dr. Wafaa El-Sadr, a professor at Columbia University, by surprise. “People in my world always felt there was a possibility of a pandemic by a new virus,” she said, “but the magnitude and speed at which it happened, and the profound impact on the world, was beyond what I imagined.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Krauss
title: New in Paperback: ‘Hamnet’ and ‘All the Way to the Tigers’
description: Six new paperbacks to check out this week.
content: HAMNET: A Novel of the Plague, by Maggie O’Farrell. (Vintage, 320 pp., $16.95.) At the center of this National Book Critics Circle Award winner — one of the Book Review’s 10 Best Books of 2020 — is the question of why Shakespeare may have titled his most famous play for his son, who died at age 11. According to our reviewer, Geraldine Brooks, O’Farrell’s novel is at once about “the transfiguration of life into art” and a “master class” in how the author herself does it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mihir Zaveri and Michael Gold
title: Here are five takeaways from the first Democratic debate for mayor of New York City.
description: Andrew Yang behaved, and was attacked, like a front-runner. Maya Wiley came out swinging. And all eight candidates tried to stand out in an awkward virtual debate format.
content: The debate was spirited, at times fast-paced and occasionally awkward, with the eight candidates for the Democratic nomination for mayor of New York engaging with one another in a virtual format that left little room for the usual onstage theatrics. Here are five takeaways.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Hurley
title: Losers, Lovers, Strivers: The 60-Second Novelist Is Ready to Listen
description: After a year of isolation, a writer of speedy life stories takes to the street to commune with strangers again, plying the form he came up with nearly 40 years ago.
content: The day after the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention announced that fully vaccinated people could safely go outside without masks, I headed to the street with my 1941 Remington typewriter, folding chair and a little sign that read, “Your Life Story in About a Minute.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mitch Smith, Sarah Mervosh and Julie Bosman
title: What Does the New Mask Guidance Really Mean?
description: The C.D.C. now says it is safe for fully vaccinated people to take their masks off in most indoor settings. States, cities and businesses were sorting through what to do with the guidance.
content: More than a year after federal health officials told Americans to cover their faces when venturing out in public, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said on Thursday that fully vaccinated people could start taking off their masks indoors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: The Lost Days of Raúl Jiménez
description: Raúl Jiménez remembers arriving in London with his Wolverhampton Wanderers teammates. He remembers walking onto the field at the Emirates Stadium an hour or so before that November game against Arsenal, briefly taking in his surroundings and heading back inside to get changed. He would, as usual, be leading the Wolves attack.
content: Raúl Jiménez remembers arriving in London with his Wolverhampton Wanderers teammates. He remembers walking onto the field at the Emirates Stadium an hour or so before that November game against Arsenal, briefly taking in his surroundings and heading back inside to get changed. He would, as usual, be leading the Wolves attack.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mitch Smith
title: How Do You Feel About the New Mask Guidelines?
description: The C.D.C. said fully vaccinated people don’t have to wear masks or maintain social distance indoors or outdoors, with some exceptions. But what do you plan on doing in the coming weeks?
content: Federal health officials said on Thursday that people who were at least two weeks past their final dose of a coronavirus vaccine could safely go most places, both indoors and outdoors, without a mask. Governors and mayors across much of the country have since announced plans to relax or end their mask mandates. The changing and differing guidelines across state lines have led to some people feeling confused or unsure what advice to follow.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stanley Reed
title: British Fraud Unit Is Investigating Gupta and Greensill
description: The inquiry will focus a spotlight on a steel magnate and a financier whose business collapse has provoked a scandal in Britain.
content: Britain’s financial crime unit is investigating suspected fraud and money laundering involving the businesses of Sanjeev Gupta, whose global metals empire ballooned in recent years with the aid of billions of dollars in financing from the failed  firm Greensill Capital.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Roose
title: He’s a Dogecoin Millionaire. And He’s Not Selling.
description: Glauber Contessoto went looking for something that could change his fortunes overnight. He found it in a joke cryptocurrency.
content: Last February, when Glauber Contessoto decided to invest his life savings in Dogecoin, his friends had concerns.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erik Piepenburg
title: What to Know About ‘Spiral’ and the ‘Saw’ Franchise
description: Not sure if the new horror movie “Spiral: From the Book of Saw” is for you? Our primer will help you decide.
content: You don’t have to know a thing about the horror movie “Saw” or its spawn before watching the latest movie in the franchise, “Spiral: From the Book of Saw,” opening in theaters on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariq Panja
title: A Barcelona Star on Style, Substance and Another Champions League Final
description: Lieke Martens and Barcelona will face Chelsea on Sunday. Both have their sights set on raising the standard for success in the women’s game.
content: In many ways, the trajectory of Lieke Martens’s career has mirrored the growth of professional women’s soccer in Europe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Lee Myers
title: The Moon, Mars and Beyond: China’s Ambitious Plans in Space
description: The country’s high-profile Mars mission is one of many on its schedule as it seeks to challenge American dominance of space exploration.
content: China has now accomplished something that only the United States and (very briefly) the Soviet Union had done before: a successful landing on Mars.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charanna Alexander
title: Love Letter: The Benefits of Childhood Friends
description: And: Quickie weddings come to Brooklyn.
content: We all remember our first childhood friend. The one you were always excited to see. The one who made every play date feel like an adventure. And most important, the one who accepted you completely, quirks and all.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Cusumano
title: Make Time to Mourn
description: Though the pandemic has posed obstacles to funerals, delaying memorial services has also opened up unexpected opportunities for reflection and creativity.
content: After the death of a loved one, the grief of each survivor is often different — but the ritual of holding a funeral is shared.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By C. J. Hughes
title: The North Fork Has Its Own Market Moment
description: A steady stream of buyers intent on finding good deals and open spaces during the pandemic has meant record sales and rising prices.
content: Home prices have been climbing on the North Fork for years now, but the market went into overdrive when the pandemic hit, and the impact could be long-term.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Will We All Want to Be Wearing Halston Soon?
description: A new Netflix show could create the viral fashion trend of summer. Except the clothes play second fiddle to the divadom and drama.
content: It was bound to happen. After the viral trendsetting of the ’60s shifts in “The Queen’s Gambit” and the ’80s puff sleeves of “The Crown,” it was only a matter of time before Netflix embraced fashion as the Next Great Brand Extension. And what better test than a show based entirely on the life and times of a great designer?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giovanni Russonello
title: A Breakaway Third Party of Ex-Republicans? Don’t Count on It.
description: The idea of a conservative anti-Trump party gained publicity this week — but the threat remains hollow.
content: “A house divided against itself cannot stand,” Abraham Lincoln declared in 1858, just two years before he assumed the mantle of the recently formed Republican Party. “It will become all one thing or all the other.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pardis Parker
title: The Bear Chased Us. Then We Chased the Bear.
description: When I was young and new in town, my next-door neighbor became my friend and protector.
content: The bear chased us. Then we chased the bear.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Erlanger
title: Arab World Condemns Israeli Violence but Takes Little Action
description: By saying it is defending Jerusalem, Hamas has made it harder for Arab countries not to denounce Israel. But in a changed region, the response so far has been rhetorical only.
content: BRUSSELS — The Arab world is unified in condemning Israeli airstrikes in Gaza and the way the Israeli police invaded Jerusalem’s Aqsa Mosque, one of Islam’s holiest sites. Governments have spoken out, protests have taken place, social media is aflame.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shashank Bengali
title: Singapore announces new restrictions after vaccinated airport workers become infected.
description: The cluster of cases suggested the ability of a “very virulent” coronavirus variant to evade inoculations, officials said. But none of the infections are believed to have caused serious illness or death.
content: SINGAPORE — Singapore said on Friday that it would ban dining in restaurants and gatherings of more than two people to try to stem a rise in coronavirus cases, becoming the latest Asian nation to reintroduce restrictions after keeping the illness mostly in check for months.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Kelly
title: A ‘Friend of Tom’ or ‘Can’t Be Bothered’: One Man’s Rules at Bank of America
description: Thomas K. Montag, the bank’s No. 2 executive, has long run its markets and corporate banking division with favoritism and an iron fist, employees say.
content: Early on in the pandemic, Bank of America found an innovative way to gauge the success of the bank’s work-from-home experiment: a spreadsheet, distributed to team managers daily, that pitted the productivity of people working from home against those who were still showing up at the office.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck
title: Candidates Clash Over Future of New York in First Mayoral Debate
description: The eight Democrats competing to win the June 22 primary presented divergent views on how to lead the city in a sometimes acerbic debate.
content: The two leading candidates in the New York City mayor’s race battled to protect their advantages in a hard-hitting Democratic debate on Thursday evening while their six rivals grasped for breakout moments, sought to redefine the stakes of the contest and put forth their own visions for the struggling city.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora and Elian Peltier
title: The variant first detected in India is forcing the U.K. to speed up delivery of second doses of vaccine.
description: British officials are considering targeted vaccinations and renewed restrictions after the number of cases of the variant tripled in just over a week.
content: LONDON — Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain said on Friday that vaccination protocols would be changed to swiftly deliver second doses to people over 50-years-old to combat the spread of a coronavirus variant first detected in India, a warning sign for countries that are easing restrictions even though their own vaccination campaigns are incomplete.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vincent M. Mallozzi
title: First a ‘Third Wheel,’ Then a Couple
description: Dr. Christine Gruessner and Przemyslaw Grabowski met while he was on a date with her best friend. “They didn’t hit it off, but we did,” she said.
content: When asked what they believed brought them together in December 2017, Dr. Christine Gruessner and Przemyslaw Grabowski each offered an explanation that could be summed up in a single word: magnetism.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Jimmy Fallon Is Psyched About Going Maskless
description: “Yeah, if you are fully vaccinated, you can go back to doing the things you did before the pandemic,” Fallon said. “Well, not everything — if you’re Trump, you still can’t tweet.”
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. We’re all stuck at home at the moment, so here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Casselman and Jim Tankersley
title: Looking for Bipartisan Accord? Just Ask About Big Business.
description: In surveys and political discourse, Republicans are increasingly critical of corporations, but not for the reasons Democrats have long held that view.
content: Republicans in Washington and around the country have soured on big business, joining Democrats in expressing concern that corporations wield too much influence. The shift has left corporate America with fewer allies in a tumultuous period for American society and the global economy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: What to Know About the Yankees’ Coronavirus Outbreak
description: Gleyber Torres is the eighth person (and the first player) from the Yankees organization to test positive for the coronavirus this week. All had been vaccinated.
content: Gleyber Torres, the Yankees’ two-time All-Star shortstop, became the eighth person involved with the Yankees organization to test positive for the coronavirus this week, the team announced on Thursday. But what has caught the attention of many outside of the baseball world is that Torres, three coaches and four support staff members had all been fully vaccinated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sergio Garcia Sanchez
title: Visualizing Robert Frost’s Seminal Poem
description: The illustrator Sergio Garcia Sanchez embarks on the road not taken.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: Why the C.D.C. Changed Its Advice on Masks
description: Two scientific findings altered the calculus: Vaccinated people don’t transmit the virus, and the shots are effective against variants.
content: Advice from federal health officials that fully vaccinated people could drop their masks in most settings came as a surprise to Americans, from state officials to scientific experts. Even the White House got less than a day’s notice from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, the press secretary, Jen Psaki, said at a news briefing on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Curtis Chang and Kris Carter
title: Our Fellow Evangelicals Need to Get Vaccinated
description: We're worried that our community is obstructing the end of the pandemic.
content: The pathway to ending the Covid-19 pandemic runs through the evangelical church. Tens of millions of evangelical Christians live in the United States, and almost half of white evangelicals surveyed have said they are reluctant to get vaccinated against Covid. For many outside the evangelical world, this resistance seems incomprehensible. But as lifelong evangelicals, we understand why this is happening, and we worry that our community is obstructing recovery from the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Rosa
title: First Shots for a Younger Set of New Yorkers
description: What 12-to-15-year-olds had to say as they received their  doses: “I’ll tell generations after me how we got through this.”
content: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Victor
title: Target Stops Selling Pokémon Cards, Citing Safety Concerns in Stores
description: The game, first released in 1996, has seen a resurgence in recent years. The pandemic sent demand for some cards into overdrive.
content: The intense demand for Pokémon trading cards, which steadily rose in recent years then rocketed up even more during the pandemic, has caused Target to temporarily suspend sales of the cards, citing a threat to the safety of customers and workers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson
title: In Stefanik, G.O.P. Installs a Trump Convert Who Reflects the Party’s Shift
description: Once a moderate, Representative Elise Stefanik of New York, the party’s new No. 3 in the House, tacked to the right as her party and district rallied behind Donald J. Trump.
content: WASHINGTON — As Representative Elise Stefanik of New York watched then-candidate Donald J. Trump take her party by storm and win the Republican presidential nomination in 2016, she was so skeptical of his inflammatory style and hard-right positions that she refused — even when pressed — to say his name.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Troy Closson
title: The Spike in Shootings During the Pandemic May Outlast the Virus
description: About 505 people were shot in New York City through May 9, the highest year-to-date number in a decade.
content: A man in Queens was fatally shot in the stomach outside a celebration thrown for his birthday. Another in the Bronx who stopped to check on a stranger’s well-being was struck in the head and torso and died. A 17-year-old was killed near his school in Brooklyn after end-of-day dismissal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin and David Poller
title: Masks, Israel, Tim Duncan: Your Friday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

title: Louis Menand on ‘The Free World’
description: Menand talks about his work of political and cultural history, and Phillip Lopate discusses his three anthologies of American essays.
content: Louis Menand’s new book, “The Free World: Art and Thought in the Cold War,” covers the interchange of arts and ideas between the United States and Europe in the decades after World War II. On this week’s podcast, Menand talks about the book, including why he chose to frame his telling from the end of the war until 1965.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: M.L.B. and Players’ Union File Grievances Against Each Other
description: The players are seeking $500 million for the shortened 2020 season. The Yankees beat Baltimore and the Mets lost to Tampa Bay.
content: The Major League Baseball Players’ Association recently filed a grievance over the shortened 2020 season, as they had threatened to do since negotiations with the league soured last summer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear, Nicole Perlroth and Clifford Krauss
title: Colonial Pipeline Paid Roughly $5 Million in Ransom to Hackers
description: The payment clears the way for gas to begin flowing again, but it risks emboldening other criminal groups to take American companies hostage by seizing control of their computers.
content: WASHINGTON — The operator of a critical fuel pipeline on the East Coast paid extortionists roughly 75 Bitcoin — or nearly $5 million — to recover its stolen data, according to people briefed on the transaction, clearing the way for gas to begin flowing again but complicating President Biden’s efforts to deter future attacks.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Beatific Re-emergence of Beverly Glenn-Copeland
description: A conversation about his winding path to a receptive, ready audience — and how music can be a bulwark against cynicism and trauma.
content: For decades, Beverly Glenn-Copeland made music heard by a precious few. In the early 1970s, he trained in classical music performance, and then released a couple of folk albums. In the 1980s, he made new age keyboard music. For the most part, he worked in children’s television.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Daniels
title: Stream These 5 Action Films Now
description: This month’s picks include the animated “New Gods: Nezha Reborn,” the neo-western “Pixie” and the fantastical “Super Me,” the crime thriller “Adverse” and the comic “Get the Goat.”
content: For the action movie fans looking for new thrills to watch at home, there are a lot of car chases, explosions and sword and fist fights to sift through. Let me help you by providing some streaming highlights. This month’s picks include films from around the globe and tonally range from spell-bindingly fantastical to the surprisingly comical.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: Ex-Aide to Congressman Claims He Was Fired for Voicing Virus Concerns
description: A former adviser to Representative Doug Lamborn, a Colorado Republican, contends in a federal lawsuit that the congressman flouted safety guidelines, contributing to an outbreak in his office.
content: A former aide to Representative Doug Lamborn, Republican of Colorado, filed a lawsuit on Thursday claiming that he was fired after complaining about his boss’s disregard for safety measures meant to protect congressional staff members from the coronavirus, which he said resulted in an outbreak in Mr. Lamborn’s office.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Ellentuck
title: ‘We’re Hungry’: The Liberty Aim High in a Bounce-Back Season
description: The Liberty had the worst record in the W.N.B.A. last year. But the return of Sabrina Ionescu and the addition of league veterans could turn things around.
content: Liberty Coach Walt Hopkins and his staff reviewed last season’s film looking for answers beyond the box scores and advanced analytics. Why was their defensive rating so low? Who was getting burned on screens? It was a trying year for a first-year head coach and his team, which ended with the second-worst winning percentage in W.N.B.A. history and a 2-20 record.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Lee Myers and Kenneth Chang
title: China’s Mars Rover Mission Lands on the Red Planet
description: The success establishes China as a principal contender in what some see as a new era of space competition.
content: The United States now has company on Mars.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dashiell Young-Saver
title: The Math of Ending the Pandemic: Exponential Growth and Decay
description: In this lesson, students will explore how the mathematical concepts of exponential growth and exponential decay help to explain the spread and slowdown of the coronavirus.
content: Featured article: “The Math That Explains the End of the Pandemic”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: A Deep Look at One Classroom
description: A reporter’s embed with a high school class tells the story of this interrupted, destabilizing school year.
content: Susan Dominus, a staff writer at The New York Times Magazine, spent much of the school year with one sophomore class in Columbia, Mo. Today we’re breaking our usual weekly schedule to tell you about her phenomenal article chronicling the experience.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Anthes
title: Pfizer and Moderna vaccines are powerfully effective against Covid-19, a C.D.C. analysis confirmed.
description: A new study of 1,800 health care workers confirms that the vaccines are working well in the real world, outside clinical trials.
content: The Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna coronavirus vaccines are 94 percent effective at preventing symptomatic Covid-19 illness, according to a new study of more than 1,800 health care workers in the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Sullivan
title: Faith-Based Investing Makes Up Ground in Gains and Convenience
description: Investing according to theological beliefs “is much easier to do now,” a wealth adviser said. It’s also as profitable as investing without a religious screen, and no more risky.
content: The intersection of faith and money can be complicated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Julian E. Barnes
title: Spy Agencies Seek New Afghan Allies as U.S. Withdraws
description: The move signals an acknowledgment by Western intelligence agencies that they are preparing for the likely collapse of the central government and a return to civil war.
content: KABUL, Afghanistan — Western spy agencies are evaluating and courting regional leaders outside the Afghan government who might be able to provide intelligence about terrorist threats long after U.S. forces withdraw, according to current and former American, European and Afghan officials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ashley Abramson
title: Filling Your Summer Calendar? Slow Your Roll.
description: Are you completely vaccinated and eager to pack your schedule to the brim? Ease up, Turbo, downtime is good for you.
content: When Mayor Bill de Blasio announced New York’s summer reopening, Daniel Roque-Coplin and his girlfriend saw a chance to rekindle their relationship after a year spent on the couch watching Netflix. But soon, the promise of a summer visiting bars, restaurants and museums they had frequented prepandemic felt more overwhelming than exciting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mihir Zaveri
title: Andrew Yang was put on the defensive about his voting record and his role in Georgia Senate election.
description: Candidates attacked Mr. Yang as being out of touch with New York City voters and taking too much credit for his role in the Georgia Senate elections.
content: Andrew Yang, who has been criticized multiple times during the campaign for being out of touch with New York City voters, found himself on the defensive once again during the debate, when Erroll Louis, the moderator, pressed him on the fact that he had not voted in several local elections.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner
title: Gaza Rocket Finds a Rare Gap in Israeli Armor, and a Boy Is Killed
description: When a rocket struck an Israeli border town, Ido Avigal, 5, was sheltering in a fortified safe room. But shrapnel still managed to puncture the thick window, killing him.
content: SDEROT, Israel — It was 1:30 p.m. on Friday in Sderot, and Ido Avigal, 5, was being laid to rest a few miles to the north. He had been killed in what officials termed a freak incident two days earlier when a rocket from Gaza made a direct hit on the building next door to his aunt’s apartment, where he was visiting with his mother and older sister.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reuters
title: Stocks Rally but End the Week With a Loss
description: The S&P 500 gained 1.5 percent on Friday, but was still 1.4 percent below last week’s close.
content: Wall Street ended Friday higher at the close of a broad rally, an upbeat conclusion to whipsaw week of buying and selling as signs of a rebounding economy did battle with mounting inflation jitters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David McCabe and Cecilia Kang
title: As Congress Dithers, States Step In to Set Rules for the Internet
description: Virginia, Florida, Arkansas and Maryland are among dozens of states that have introduced bills to curtail the power of Amazon, Google, Facebook and Twitter.
content: WASHINGTON — News outlets in Florida may soon be able to sue Facebook and Twitter if the social media companies take down their content.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Engle
title: What Is the Best Way to Get Teenagers Vaccinated?
description: The F.D.A. has approved the coronavirus vaccine for 12- to 15-year-olds. Will you and your peers get the shots? Do you or your family have any hesitations?
content: On Monday, the Food and Drug Administration authorized the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine for children ages 12 to 15 in the United States, a crucial step in the nation’s recovery from the pandemic and a boon to millions of American families eager for a return to normalcy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard C. Paddock
title: Miss Universe Myanmar Arrives in Florida With a Message for the Junta
description: Ma Thuzar Wint Lwin hopes to use her international platform as a pageant contestant to criticize the country’s military coup and support the pro-democracy movement.
content: As a girl, Ma Thuzar Wint Lwin would watch the Miss Universe pageant and wish that she could be the one onstage representing her country, Myanmar. She entered her first two contests last year, nervous and excited about what to expect. But she ultimately walked away crowned Miss Universe Myanmar, and this week is competing at the global pageant in Florida.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: rescind
description: This word has appeared in 115 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Abrams
title: ‘No Smile, No Trash Talk’: Behind Tim Duncan’s Quiet Excellence
description: A bank shot carried Duncan from St. Croix to Wake Forest, five championships with the Spurs and now the Hall of Fame.
content: Tim Duncan stoically spent 19 fundamentally sound seasons allowing his play to speak for him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: Eight people from the New York Yankees organization tested positive, despite having been vaccinated. Here’s what to know.
description: Gleyber Torres, the Yankees’ two-time All-Star shortstop, became the eighth person involved with the Yankees organization to test positive for the coronavirus this week, the team announced on Thursday. But what has caught the attention of many outside of the baseball world is that Torres, three coaches and four support staff members had all been fully vaccinated.
content: Gleyber Torres, the Yankees’ two-time All-Star shortstop, became the eighth person involved with the Yankees organization to test positive for the coronavirus this week, the team announced on Thursday. But what has caught the attention of many outside of the baseball world is that Torres, three coaches and four support staff members had all been fully vaccinated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hilarie Ashton
title: Comfort Viewing: 3 Reasons I Love ‘The Nanny’
description: The ’90s sitcom starring Fran Drescher has caused a sartorial sensation since all six seasons arrived on HBO Max. It is also, the writer argues, a delightful show that unlike some of its contemporaries, still feels fresh.
content: Since the arrival of all six seasons of “The Nanny” on HBO Max last month, there were a couple of weeks when it seemed as if everyone I knew or followed was watching. If, while stuck indoors, you’ve been a little too glued to social media, you may have seen the excited posts and whole accounts devoted to the glory of Fran Drescher’s wit and fashion sense. Style writers have been effusive, calling the show “iconic,” a “master class in sitcom fashion” and “wonderfully horny.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nancy Sherman
title: If You’re Reading Stoicism for Life Hacks, You’re Missing the Point
description: It’s not about self-improvement. It’s about being a good member of society.
content: Modern Stoicism has become an industry. And a mega-industry at that.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Marino
title: The Writer Kati Marton Is Selling Her Cottage in Southampton
description: The three-bedroom house, where Ms. Marton and the diplomat Richard C. Holbrooke had spent weekends, is on the market for $4.65 million.
content: For the author Kati Marton, the Hamptons have been a welcome haven for many years, especially Southampton.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gabe Cohn
title: They Met Online. Through Wikipedia, That Is.
description: Courtney Thurston and Matthew Del Buono first met in chat rooms they frequented as contributors to the online encyclopedia.
content: When Courtney Elizabeth Thurston and Matthew Paul Del Buono first met in person, they didn’t know each other as Courtney Thurston and Matthew Del Buono; they knew each other as IShadowed and Shirik. Those were the aliases that Ms. Thurston and Mr. Del Buono used as contributors to Wikipedia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Drape and Melissa Hoppert
title: Expert Picks: Who Will Win the Preakness?
description: Joe Drape and Melissa Hoppert look at the contenders for the 146th Preakness Stakes.
content: Medina Spirit, who won the Kentucky Derby on May 1 to give the trainer Bob Baffert a record seventh victory in the race, was installed as the 9-5 morning-line favorite in Saturday’s Preakness Stakes, despite nearly not running at all after it was disclosed that he had tested positive for betamethasone, a corticosteroid, after the Derby.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Ezra Klein Show'
title: Status Games, Polyamory and the Merits of Meritocracy
description: Can meritocracy ever be ethical? The philosopher Agnes Callard thinks so.
content: Agnes Callard is an ethical philosopher who dissects, in dazzlingly precise detail, familiar human experiences that we think we understand. Whether her topic is expressing anger, fighting with others, jockeying for status, giving advice or navigating jealousy, Callard provokes us to rethink the emotions and habits that govern how we live. She also happens to be one of my favorite columnists.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helen T. Verongos
title: Leftovers From a Doughnut, Say
description: Yacob Yonas directs us to a coffee spot, as well.
content: FRIDAY PUZZLE — Yacob Yonas has a way of evoking a specific memory, of making a solitary solver laugh out loud and then stopping us dead with a seemingly light clue that leads to a weighty answer. He does all three in this puzzle, his eighth crossword for The New York Times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Knoll
title: Avalanche Are Cup Favorites, but Even the Islanders Can Dream
description: The playoffs open on Saturday with Game 1 between the Capitals and Bruins, one of the eight first-round matchups. Things look a little different this year.
content: The N.H.L. playoffs begin on Saturday the same way the 56-game regular season played out: the schedule featured entirely intradivisional play and the postseason will be no different through the first two rounds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Halpert
title: Emptying the Nest. Again.
description: Many young adults moved back in with their parents during the pandemic. Now the parents are facing a second exodus.
content: When Kristine Mestaz’s son, Jeremy Cunningham, now 20, moved to Arizona for college, she was sad but supportive and grew accustomed to his absence. Then the pandemic happened and her nest was refilled: He returned home to Auburn, Calif., in March 2020 for spring break, but didn’t leave, as his school, Arizona State University, went online.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Traub
title: Pervis Staples, Who Harmonized With the Staple Singers, Dies at 85
description: He sang alongside his father and sisters as his family’s gospel group achieved renown in the late 1950s and ’60s.
content: Pervis Staples, who sang harmony and also provided quieter forms of support during the rise to gospel stardom of his family’s group, the Staple Singers, died on May 6 at his home in Dolton, Ill. He was 85.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear, Katie Rogers and Annie Karni
title: Beneath Joe Biden’s Folksy Demeanor, a Short Fuse and an Obsession With Details
description: As Mr. Biden settles into the office he has chased for more than three decades, aides say he demands hours of debate from scores of policy experts.
content: WASHINGTON — The commander in chief was taking his time, as usual.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David M. Halbfinger
title: A Press Corps Deceived, and the Gaza Invasion That Wasn’t
description: A spokesman led the international media to believe that Israeli forces had entered Gaza. They hadn’t. But the army wanted Hamas to think they had.
content: The Israeli military abruptly announced after midnight on Friday that its ground forces had begun “attacking in the Gaza Strip,” saying it on Twitter, in text messages to journalists, and in on-the-record confirmations by an English-speaking army spokesman.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Schwirtz and Nicole Perlroth
title: DarkSide, Blamed for Gas Pipeline Attack, Says It Is Shutting Down
description: The hacking group, which the F.B.I. has said was responsible for the ransomware attack, said it had received “pressure” from the U.S.
content: The criminal hacking group DarkSide, which the F.B.I. has blamed for carrying out a ransomware attack that crippled fuel delivery across the Southeastern United States this week, has announced that it is shutting down because of unspecified “pressure” from the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Packing
description: What do you think this image is saying?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Max Fisher
title: In Israel’s Rising Violence, Ripples From 1948
description: The town of Lydda posed an early test of how the Israeli state would treat Palestinians. It is a legacy playing out today in violence between Jews and Arabs in Lod, as it’s now known.
content: On the afternoon of July 11, 1948, regiments of the newly formed state of Israel advanced toward the village of Lydda. They would conduct an operation there that, by many accounts, became formative to their new state and to the conflict that has continued ever since, and that echoes in the violence raging this week in that very same town, now known as Lod.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook This Weekend
description: Dabble in short ribs with a variety of condiments by way of Texas, or try your hand at meatless gumbo with a distinct Louisiana flavor.
content: Good morning. I wrote about the Texas restaurateur Jennifer Hwa Dobbertin for The Times this week, and of course there’s a recipe: the red-cooked short ribs (above) served at Best Quality Daughter, the restaurant Dobbertin runs with the chef Quealy Watson in San Antonio. It’s a really delicious feed, to eat as they do at the restaurant, with lettuce wraps and rice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lysley Tenorio
title: What Makes a Good Chinese Father? In a New Novel, It’s Complicated.
description: In “My Good Son,” by Yang Huang, a Chinese father strives to offer his floundering son a better life. But is he actually being a good parent?
content: MY GOOD SONBy Yang Huang
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Korsha Wilson
title: In the Virgin Islands, Fungi Tells a Story
description: Once a staple on dinner tables, the cornmeal-based dish is becoming harder to find on restaurant menus. These chefs are working to preserve it.
content: At Petite Pump Room, a waterfront restaurant in Charlotte Amalie on the island of St. Thomas, lunchtime usually finds locals and visitors filling the tables and bar, taking in the island’s hills and watching seaplanes take off and land in the harbor from nearby St. Croix.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edgar Sandoval, Kate Taylor and Mitch Smith
title: Federal Mask Retreat Sets Off Confusing Scramble for States and Cities
description: Some governors and mayors quickly rolled back their mask mandates, while others said local restrictions would stay in place for now.
content: SAN ANTONIO — Minnesota’s statewide mask mandate is over. But in Minneapolis, the state’s largest city, face coverings are still required.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Besha Rodell
title: Australia’s Never-Ending Travel Ban
description: Is it worth it, keeping the borders closed until the middle of 2022?
content: This week, it was reported that travel restrictions to and from Australia are likely to remain in place until mid-2022. For some, this won’t matter much at all — many Australians are far more grateful for the safety of our isolation than worried about the inability to travel or have overseas visitors. For others, travel has been an integral way of life, and this news comes as a disappointment and inconvenience. And then there are the thousands and thousands of people who are cut off from loved ones in a way that feels earth-shattering.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Libbey
title: United by a Deep Connection to Brooklyn
description: Michelle Lorenzutti and David Alperin met at a bar in Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn. He was waiting for a blind date; she was celebrating her birthday alone.
content: Michelle Lorenzutti and David Alperin began dating in 2019, but in some ways their love story started much earlier, when their great-grandparents arrived in Brooklyn in the first half of the 20th Century. That history turned out to be key to the connection the couple developed decades later.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Sloss
title: He Said (I Do), She Said (I Do)
description: Stacey Chen and Nick Cugini first met in high school as members of competing debating teams. In college, they were on the same side.
content: When Nick Cugini received a Facebook friend request from Stacey Chen, he was intrigued, and a little amused.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: The 2021 N.H.L. Playoffs Are Set to Begin
description: We answer your playoff hockey questions: When they start, who plays who, how you can watch, and what is all the fuss about the Stanley Cup.
content: You hear a lot of superlatives about the N.H.L. playoffs. Does hockey have the most exciting playoffs? Is the Stanley Cup the hardest trophy to win in sports? Are its customs and traditions the most mythic and profound?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luis Ferré-Sadurní
title: Here is where the candidates stand on affordable housing.
description: The city’s housing crisis has become a key issue in the mayor’s race — and not just because two candidates, Ray McGuire and Shaun Donovan, were ridiculed this week after estimating that the median price of a Brooklyn home was about $100,000. (It’s actually $900,000).

author: By Nicholas Fandos
title: Democrats Move Closer to Setting Up Jan. 6 Commission, With or Without G.O.P.
description: House Democrats plan to vote on a bill to create an independent commission to investigate the Capitol riot, but whether Republican leaders would support it was unclear.
content: WASHINGTON — House Democrats pressed ahead on Friday with a bipartisan proposal to create an independent commission to investigate the Jan. 6 Capitol attack, after reaching agreement with a key Republican to drop his party’s demand that it look at left-wing violence unrelated to the assault.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Allen
title: The Conductor Who Whipped American Orchestras Into Shape

title: Alex Rodriguez and Partner Reach Deal on Timberwolves and Lynx

content: In her three years in the national spotlight, Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez has become the undisputed face of unabashed progressivism. But there is another hidden-in-plain-sight legacy of her 2018 primary victory: Her campaign logo and poster have reshaped the visual branding of the left.

content: Chad Kalepa Baybayan, a revered Hawaiian seafarer who was a torchbearer for the art of “wayfinding,” which ancestral Polynesian sailors used to navigate the Pacific Ocean by studying the stars, trade winds and flight patterns of birds, died on April 8 at a friend’s home in Seattle. He was 64.

content: Americans are penciling in higher inflation not just over the next year but over the next five years, according to a survey measure that Federal Reserve officials have a history of watching closely. author: By Nancy Hass
title: Giorgio Armani’s Perfect Wire-Rimmed Glasses
description: Since he debuted them in the ’80s, the designer has refined his signature oval specs here and there, but always maintained their classic appeal.
content: GIORGIO ARMANI, NOW 86 and still leading the Milan-based fashion house he founded in 1975, is a master of expansion and evolution. Since gaining international attention with Richard Gere’s wardrobe in Paul Schrader’s noirish 1980 film “American Gigolo,” the designer liberated a generation of men from boxy black-and-navy Brooks Brothers conformity with his draped linen jackets and suits in shades of dove and cappuccino. Informed by the traditions of Italian tailoring, Japanese aesthetics and Art Deco, his empire now encompasses everything from furnishings to fragrance, but he has never wavered in his dedication to monochromatic modernity.
